thread.title: Two Knoxville teams advance to USTA nationals - News Sentinel
thread.title_full: Two Knoxville teams advance to USTA nationals - News Sentinel Story

author: Jimmy Hyams
title: Two Knoxville teams advance to USTA nationals - News Sentinel
text:
Two Knoxville teams won USTA Southern Sectionals and will advance to the national tournament later this month.
The 55-plus women's 3.0 team plays out of Cedar Bluff Racquet Club went 4-0 in the sectional round in Asheville, N.C. The team beat Alabama 2-1 in the final.
Co-captains were Teresa Helton and Scott Thompson. Team members are Cyndi Thompson, Gail Rieger, Carolyn Hutsell, Elaine Vandiver, Shirley McMichael, Helen Sunshine and Anita Rule.
Nationals will be held Oct. 23-25 in Surprise, Ariz.
The Cedar Bluff Racquet Club 14-under intermediate team went 5-0 in the sectional round at Lexington, S.C. Coach Derek Stultz's squad beat Georgia in the final, 29-23.
The match was tied 21-21 when the Knoxville team won two mixed doubles matches 4-1 to pull away.
Team members are Emily Chung, Gabby Simcic, Richa Nathan, Keileen Cullen, Ben Aikens, Jacob Pearson and Bill Malkes.
The national tournament is scheduled for Oct. 16-18 in Lexington, S.C.
Nedkov Goes Undefeated: Leo Nedkov went 8-0 at the Southern Level One tournament in Huntsville, Ala.
Nedkov, who plays out of Knoxville Racquet Club, won all four of his singles and doubles matches. In the team event, he played No. 3 singles and No. 2 doubles.
Nedkov said "meeting other high level players from different states" was the highlight of the weekend.
"Leo's progress over the last year has been remarkable, and he continues to improve in his quest to become one of the best players in the South," said Jim Frederick, Nedkov's coach.
Nedkov is the first recipient of the KREST (Knoxville Racquet Education and Support of Tennis) scholarship, given to boys and girls that are on free and assisted lunches who show promise. Recipients must maintain a high level academically as well as a positive attitude in developing tennis skills.
Single Him Out: Tennessee sophomore Igor Smelyanski had an up-and-down first year with the Vols, going 11-14 in singles, but 18-7 in doubles.
This year, the 6-foot-2 native of Israel has turned his singles game around, winning tournaments at Georgia Tech and Princeton.
"He has a really good all-around game,'' said Chris Woodruff, UT's associate head coach. "A good first serve, forehand, backhand and he can volley. He has no holes. He's very fast. He has a lot of potential.''
Woodruff said Smelyanski, who played Junior Davis Cup for Israel, is also a hard worker.
"That's his best trait," Woodruff said. "When he steps on the court, he's pretty consistent."
While Smelyanski was 1-4 in SEC singles play, he went 7-1 in the SEC doubles with Andrew Dromsky.
DeBord Connection: When Woodruff interviewed for the Michigan men's tennis job in the summer of 2014, the person that interviewed him from the athletic department was Mike DeBord, now Tennessee's offensive coordinator.
Michigan hired Adam Steinberg of Pepperdine.
Club Team Competes: The University of Tennessee Knoxville Club tennis team will compete in the USTA Tennis On Campus Fall Invitational scheduled for Oct. 9-11 in Hilton Head, S.C.
The first 48 schools to sign up got a slot in the co-ed intramural tournament.
The top two teams in the Gold Bracket receive an automatic bid to the 2016 USTA Tennis On Campus national championships.
Two at Sectionals: Knoxville's 55-plus and 65-plus 7.0 mixed doubles teams will play in the Southern Sectionals Oct. 23-25 in Little Rock, Ark.
Each team is coached by Scott Thompson.
State Closed Event: The Tennessee State Closed Adult championships will be held Oct. 16-18 at Cedar Bluff.
Divisions will be held for men's and women's singles and doubles and mixed doubles. A consolation bracket for first-round losers in singles and doubles will be held.
Clay courts and outdoor hard courts will be used.
Entry deadline is Oct. 11. The fee is $54.25 for singles, $28 per person for doubles. Call 865- 690-5700.
Knoxville also will host the Combo 18-and-over and 55-and-over Championships scheduled for Oct. 23-25.
Challenger Dates: The annual Knoxville Challenger tournament is Nov. 10-15 at UT's Goodfriend Indoor Center.
Tournament sponsorship already has exceeded $230,000. Proceeds benefit the Helen Ross McNabb Center.
Jimmy Hyams is a freelance contributor.
